author: Marta Leite Ferreira
title: Falta de neve estÃ¡ a ameaÃ§ar a sobrevivÃªncia das estÃ¢ncias de esqui na Europa | AlteraÃ§Ãµes climÃ¡ticas | PÃšBLICO
text: Falta de neve estÃ¡ a ameaÃ§ar a sobrevivÃªncia das estÃ¢ncias de esqui na Europa AlteraÃ§Ãµes climÃ¡ticas estÃ£o a provocar granizo e chuvas fortes, mas nÃ£o neva. HÃ¡ estÃ¢ncias de esqui na Europa sem capacidade para funcionar em pleno. Atletas querem mais acÃ§Ã£o climÃ¡tica. As estÃ¢ncias de esqui estÃ£o a sofrer as consequÃªncias das [alteraÃ§Ãµes climÃ¡ticas](https://www.publico.pt/2023/08/18/azul/noticia/viver-alteracoes-climaticas-tempo-real-2060609), com a chuva e o granizo a substituir a queda de neve nos destinos turÃ­sticos mais procurados na Europa. Ã‰ a confirmaÃ§Ã£o de um aviso que surgiu num estudo publicado em Agosto pela [revista Nature](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41558-023-01759-5#author-information), de que 53% das 28 estÃ¢ncias europeias investigadas pelos cientistas estavam em risco muito elevado de registar uma escassez de neve caso a temperatura mÃ©dia global aumente 2 graus Celsius em relaÃ§Ã£o aos nÃ­veis prÃ©-industriais. O [turismo de neve nos Alpes](https://www.publico.pt/2023/09/21/fugas/noticia/estancia-esqui-encerra-permanentemente-falta-neve-alpes-franceses-2064033), por exemplo, estÃ¡ avaliado em mais de 27 mil milhÃµes de euros, mas o mercado deve registar uma quebra este ano, conta um artigo do [The Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/dec/26/ski-resorts-battle-for-a-future-as-snow-declines-in-climate-crisis). Duas estÃ¢ncias de esqui em FranÃ§a, em Morzine e Les Gets, sÃ³ puderam abrir na totalidade a 23 de Dezembro, dois dias antes do Natal e a Ã©poca onde se regista uma maior afluÃªncia de turistas â€” tudo porque [choveu intensamente nos Ãºltimos dias](https://www.publico.pt/2023/06/28/azul/noticia/chuva-vai-ameaca-maior-montanhas-aquecimento-global-2054853), mas nevou pouco. A queda de pequenas quantidades de neve pode ser suficiente para manter em funcionamento algumas estÃ¢ncias de esqui mais pequenas, mas pode [ficar aquÃ©m da neve necessÃ¡ria em estÃ¢ncias com pistas maiores](https://www.publico.pt/2023/01/06/azul/noticia/janeiro-quente-so-neve-artificial-mantem-esqui-vivo-partes-suica-2034011). A produÃ§Ã£o artificial de neve traz dificuldades acrescidas por ser mais cara, consumir muita energia e muita Ã¡gua, refere a notÃ­cia do diÃ¡rio britÃ¢nico. Com ela, a quantidade de estÃ¢ncias europeias com risco elevada de perda de cobertura de neve desce para metade (27%) com um aumento da temperatura mÃ©dia global de 2ÂºC acima dos nÃ­veis prÃ©-industriais. Mas o consumo de Ã¡gua pode ser nove vezes superior atÃ© 2100 nos Alpes franceses. Os atletas profissionais estÃ£o preocupados com o impacto das alteraÃ§Ãµes climÃ¡ticas nas estÃ¢ncias, que podem a afectar 98% dos espaÃ§os analisados no [estudo da Nature](https://www.publico.pt/2023/08/29/azul/noticia/crise-climatica-vai-dificultar-futuro-50-estacoes-esqui-europeias-2061549) caso a temperatura mÃ©dia global aumente 4ÂºC em relaÃ§Ã£o aos nÃ­veis prÃ©-industriais. Segundo a [NBC News](https://www.nbcsports.com/olympics/news/alpine-skiing-climate-change-world-cup-schedule), uma carta assinada por 500 atletas de desportos da neve em Fevereiro pediu Ã  FederaÃ§Ã£o Internacional de Esqui uma maior actuaÃ§Ã£o contra as alteraÃ§Ãµes climÃ¡ticas. Mais tarde, em Outubro, mais de 35 mil pessoas assinaram uma petiÃ§Ã£o com o mesmo apelo. SÃ£o crÃ­ticas que chegam jÃ¡ depois de Gian Franco Kasper, presidente da FederaÃ§Ã£o, ter sido demitido e substituÃ­do por Johan Eliasch que foi criticado por ser negacionista no que diz respeito Ã s alteraÃ§Ãµes climÃ¡ticas causadas pelo homem. O autor da petiÃ§Ã£o, Dom Winter, da Protect our Winters UK, defendeu que a reduÃ§Ã£o do aquecimento global pode evitar o desaparecimento da neve nas estÃ¢ncias utilizadas para a prÃ¡tica de desporto â€” embora se continue a correr o risco de se tornarem "elitistas". "Certamente que, com 2ÂºC [de aquecimento global], os resorts de altitude mais baixa estariam em grandes apuros. Ainda haverÃ¡ lugares com neve natural nos Alpes e os resorts em altitudes mais elevadas podem sobreviver. A preocupaÃ§Ã£o Ã© quÃ£o cara se pode tornar esta opÃ§Ã£o", alertou, citado pelo [The Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/dec/26/ski-resorts-battle-for-a-future-as-snow-declines-in-climate-crisis).

author: Tyler Durden
title: The Chicago Mayor's Hat Trick Of Dreadful Policies | ZeroHedge
text: The Chicago Mayor's Hat Trick Of Dreadful Policies [Authored by Charles Lipson via The Epoch Times](https://realclearwire.com/articles/2023/12/27/the_chicago_mayors_hat_trick_of_dreadful_policies_150250.html) (emphasis ours), When your city elects a mayor whose main job qualification is â€œorganizer for the Chicago Teachers Union,â€ you get what you paid for, or rather what the powerful CTU paid for. With Mayor Brandon Johnson, you get a special bonus, an unwelcome one. His proposed policies are unworkable, unaffordable, and deeply unpopular in the city that elected him less than a year ago. Three policies stand out for particular ridicule. Mayor Johnson wants to: Start city-owned and -operated groceries in some underserved areas. The government that wants to take on these difficult new tasks is already failing at such basic services as fixing potholes and policing dangerous neighborhoods. Ticket the buses bringing illegal immigrants to Chicago, mostly from Texas. He calls them â€œrogue busesâ€ because they are not â€œcoordinatingâ€ with the city. Giving them a ticket or even impounding the vehicles is his solution. The bus companiesâ€™ own solution is to drop off the passengers in the suburbs, which immediately send them to Chicago. Johnson then rages at the Texas governor and never mentions President Biden. Close down all the selective-enrollment (magnet) schools in Chicago, the only ones where students actually read above grade level. If we judge by the likely outcome, Johnsonâ€™s policy is really designed to drive middle-class families with kids out of the city. The teachers union backs the plan, enthusiastically. They must know how good the other schools are since the president of the CTU sends her own child to a private school. Meanwhile, she is working with Gov. JB Pritzker to kill school choice for everyone else. The local joke about Mayor Johnson is that his only success has been to lower the price of downtown Chicago real estate. How do voters like Johnsonâ€™s ideas and his administration? Not much, it turns out. His poll numbers are roughly the same as those for used car salesmen with loud suits and back lots filled with rusting clunkers. The mayorâ€™s erstwhile supporters have abandoned him. Except for the Chicago Teachers Union. The CTU is easily the most powerful union in Illinois and, most likely, the strongest local teachers union in the country. It was their members who went door-to-door for Johnsonâ€™s election. It was their members who tacked up Johnsonâ€™s campaign posters and donated the dollars for his TV ads. Now, it is their members who comprise Johnsonâ€™s dwindling band of supporters. If it werenâ€™t for them, the mayor could hold a â€œReelect Brandon Johnsonâ€ rally on a unicycle. Most of Johnsonâ€™s policies are standard-issue leftist remedies for big cities. To paraphrase Gilbert and Sullivan, â€œHe is the very model of a modern progressive mayor.â€ That model is not working. Not in Chicago and not elsewhere. Progressive mayors and prosecutors across the country have made their cities dangerous and ungovernable. Unfortunately, failure has not changed their minds or their policies. Brandon Johnson is no exception. Consider the mayorâ€™s proposal for the city to own and operate grocery stores in impoverished areas. Letâ€™s call them â€œCastroMarts.â€ Johnson is right to say some neighborhoods have become â€œfood deserts.â€ He should ask himself why that is so. Part of the answer is poverty, but those areas were poor before the grocery stores abandoned them. What changed is that those areas are now plagued with organized retail theft, which is almost never prosecuted. Without delving into the root causes of rampant crime (Kamala Harris is searching for them in Central America), itâ€™s up to local police to stop the predation, and itâ€™s up to local prosecutors to go after the robbers and looters. Thatâ€™s not happening in Chicago â€“ or in San Francisco, Washington, Seattle, Memphis, New Orleans, St. Louis, Baltimore, Cleveland, or Portland. Those city governments have abandoned their fundamental responsibilities to â€œserve and protect.â€ Is the theory here that somehow thieves wouldnâ€™t steal from city-owned grocery stores? Whatâ€™s the evidence for that â€“ or that city workers could do a better job than trained professionals? Those businesses operate on very thin margins and require efficient, experienced management. If you donâ€™t sell meat and produce quickly, they rot. The words â€œquickâ€ and â€œefficientâ€ have never been used in the same sentence as â€œChicago city worker.â€ Better adjectives would be â€œslow,â€ â€œunionized,â€ and â€œwell-paid.â€ When you apply the correct adjectives to grocery store ownership, you get sclerotic management, high prices, and an endless string of taxpayer subsidies. You will get CastroMart, not Walmart. Brandon Johnsonâ€™s notions about education are just as compelling. His latest brainstorm is to close the best schools in the city. His stated reason is â€œequity,â€ which apparently means â€œleveling down.â€ There is no allegation that admission to these selective schools is biased. It is purely merit-based. Yet Chicagoâ€™s school board, working closely with the CTU and the mayor, recently approved a plan to â€œtransition awayâ€ from these schools. Thatâ€™s a polite way of saying, â€œWe are going to kill them if we can.â€ The teachers union defends this euthanasia because of what they call the schoolsâ€™ â€œdeep inequity.â€ The facts belie the catchphrase. [Over half the students in the 11 selective high schools come from low-income families. Around 70% are black or Hispanic.](https://www.illinoispolicy.org/chicago-teachers-union-kills-excelling-schools-to-force-students-into-dysfunction/) Whereâ€™s the â€œdeep inequityâ€? Parents are up in arms. They see powerful, entrenched interests trying to deny their children a good education and cynically justifying it in the name of progressive ideals. Theyâ€™re right. Johnsonâ€™s proposals for migrants are just as popular. Chicago has long proclaimed itself a â€œsanctuary city,â€ a label it adopted when sending that virtue signal was costless. Itâ€™s not costless anymore. Chicago leadersâ€™ response is to offload all that expensive virtue onto other cities. They are retaining the â€œsanctuaryâ€ slogan, oblivious to the irony. The number of migrants coming to Chicago is still a trickle compared to those surging into Texas and Arizona across an open border. Even so, Chicago canâ€™t handle the modest numbers. It doesnâ€™t have any place to put them or any money to pay for the vital services they require. You see them now camped out on cold city streets and begging for spare change. Itâ€™s heartbreaking. Chicagoâ€™s real answer to reducing their number is â€œwinter.â€ Johnsonâ€™s original plan was to set up migrant camps across the city. Voters went berserk. Johnson got the message and backed down. His latest plan is to put the migrants in hotels and at Oâ€™Hare Airport, issue tickets to the buses that bring them, and blame it all on Texas Gov. Greg Abbott. While Johnson has no answers for this deepening mess, he didnâ€™t create it. President Biden did that. Biden is the Einstein who decided to dismantle all of Trumpâ€™s programs, such as â€œRemain in Mexico,â€ that helped stem the flow of illegals. What was Bidenâ€™s rationale? Because the programs were Trumpâ€™s. Thatâ€™s it. To replace them, Biden put in â€¦ well, nothing. Surprisingly, that has not worked well. Even the staunchest Democrats recognize the political problems that unchecked immigration is creating. Some are from pushback in the general population, which can see the failure. Some come specifically from the black community, which is furious about this wave of migrants who compete with Americans for jobs, housing, and social services. Hispanics living here legally are none too happy either. Since Democrats depend on both minorities, especially African Americans, to win elections, the internal fissures over immigration pose real problems. They divide ideological progressives from fellow leftists who are more attentive to their minority constituents. The difficulties will only get worse as the numbers keep rising and the Biden administration keeps resisting efforts to close the border. Those tensions are already visible in Chicagoâ€™s minority neighborhoods. But immigration is only one of Brandon Johnsonâ€™s headaches. On issue after issue, he has no sensible plans to move forward and few ideas about how to cope with the cityâ€™s spiraling problems. His administration is a shambles, and voters know it. They need help. In fact, they are demanding it. They want safety, education, and other basic services. They have learned to their regret that they wonâ€™t get any of them from the incompetent, unpopular ideologue in City Hall. Charles Lipson is the Peter B. Ritzma Professor of Political Science Emeritus at the University of Chicago, where he founded the Program on International Politics, Economics, and Security. He can be reached at [charles.lipson@gmail.com](mailto:charles.lipson@gmail.com).

author: Michelle Lewis
title: The world's tallest wooden wind turbine is now online | Electrek
text:
Swedish startup Modvion has built the worldâ€™s tallest wooden wind turbine tower, and itâ€™s now sending power to 400 homes in Sweden.
The 2-megawatt (MW) wooden wind turbine, sited outside Skara, northeast of Gothenburg, was built for the electric utility Varberg Energi, and itâ€™s just started providing power to Swedenâ€™s grid.
The worldâ€™s tallest wooden wind turbine has a tower thatâ€™s 344 feet (105 meters) tall. And if you include the tip of the highest blade, itâ€™s 492 feet (150 meters) tall.
The towerâ€™s thick walls have 144 layers of laminated veneer lumber. Each layer consists of 3 millimeters of sustainable spruce. The tower was built in seven sections with 28 stacked modules held together by steel fittings glued into place.
The wood is strong but lighter than steel, and Modvion says one of its main selling points is that the modular tower is easier to transport on standard roads.
Further, the wooden towers are carbon negative â€“ they not only store carbon but continue to absorb it during their lifetime. At the end of life, the tower walls can be reused as high-strength beams for the building industry.
Danish wind giant Vestas made the 2 MW turbine mounted on the wooden tower. Vestas has been a shareholder in Modvion since 2021, and this is the first project in which Modvionâ€™s tower technology and a Vestas turbine have been paired.
Modvion told the BBC that it aims to open a factory in 2027 that will manufacture 100 wooden wind turbines annually.
Top comment by Marcus R
Liked by 5 people Good to see this getting the attention it deserves Michelle. Once they have their larger towers this will be really interesting.
Just a quick input, Chalmers signed an agreement with Varberg Energi regarding the produced energy, so the electricity will "power" parts of a university and not homes - not that it physically matters in a grid though ðŸ™‚

author: Gustavo Rangel
title: Militancia revolucionaria se movilizarÃ¡ este sÃ¡bado en rechazo a la violencia
text:
Este sÃ¡bado 17 de agosto la militancia revolucionaria se movilizarÃ¡ en rechazo a los intentos de la ultraderecha por sembrar la violencia en el paÃ­s y en respaldo a la victoria electoral obtenida por el presidente de la RepÃºblica, NicolÃ¡s Maduro, del pasado 28 de julio.
La convocatoria fue realizada por el primer vicepresidente del Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), Diosdado Cabello, en su programa Con el Mazo Dando, en el que seÃ±alÃ³ que el pueblo se mantendrÃ¡ en la calle celebrando la victoria.
â€œInvito al chavismo a una marcha en toda Venezuela el dÃ­a 17 de agosto para celebrar el triunfo electoral de la RevoluciÃ³n Bolivariana. El sÃ¡bado nosotros vamos para la calle a marchar a seguir celebrando la victoria de la RevoluciÃ³n Bolivariana, ademÃ¡s tenemos dos dÃ­as que no marchamos y estoy perdiendo la costumbre y formaâ€, afirmÃ³ Cabello.
Es importante resaltar que esta movilizaciÃ³n popular ha sido convocada ante las pretensiones de la extremaderecha de volver a ejecutar acciones terroristas ese mismo dÃ­a, cuando la jefa de estos grupos violentos, MarÃ­a Corina Machado, a estado convocando a â€œmovilizaciones de calleâ€.

author: Barnell Anderson
title: DC just voted in a new bill that would add several thousand new EV chargers over the next few years
text:
The automotive industry has reached a point where many of the best new cars are all-electric. However, drivers still have significant reasons not to buy one. Specifically, there remains an electric charger problem for those who donâ€™t have one at home. Now, DC has voted in a new law that would add several thousand EV chargers over the next few years.
DC has a solution for one of the most significant barriers between all-electric cars and buyers The amount of all-electric chargers has dramatically increased in recent years. However, these changes may not be enough to support as many EVs as various entities hope. Now, according to WUSA 9 , the District of Columbia has just approved a bill called â€œRight to Charge.â€ Essentially, it seeks to make public EV chargers much more accessible for residents.
So, how does this new bill work, and will it persuade people to buy all-electric cars? Basically, it makes it so that the city adds more public electric chargers as the amount of registered EVs grows. It also seeks to make chargers a right for renters. Councilman Charles Allen says this bill will add thousands of new charges in just a few years. However, it should be noted that the current number of chargers around D.C. is proportional to the number of registered EVs.
The Councilman had this to say, â€œWe need people to go electric â€” and fast. his bill sends a clear signal that coming soon, there are going to be a lot of chargers available in places where people live, work and shop.â€
Of course, for this bill to work, officials have to tally the number of all-electric cars and provide the proper funding for chargers that represent five percent of the vehicles. This bill also includes the Electric Vehicle Charging Incentive Program, which would create vouchers for landlords to build chargers. The Department of Energy and Environment will administer this part of the bill.
Based on numbers from 2023, D.C. has about 8,100 all-electric cars and 1,057 charging stations for drivers. As mentioned, this number of chargers meets the new billâ€™s requirements. However, itâ€™s important to note that the number of EVs was up by 37 percent compared to 2022, which shows the need for continued growth.

author: Esmerelda Weatherwax
title: Pope Francis' Unholy Alliances
text:
By Eric Rozenman
One can pray for the speedy recovery of Pope Francis , 88 and hospitalized with pneumonia, while wishing that when called in 2013, Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio stayed in Argentina.
As pope, Francis has been wrong consistently. He seems unable to render â€œunto Caesar the things that are Caesarâ€™s and unto God the things that are Godâ€™s.â€
For example, five days before leaving office, the Biden administration announced removal of Cuba from the U.S. list of state sponsors of terrorism. Both sides said the Catholic Church helped arrange the deal, which involved release of Cuban political prisoners, and that President Biden had spoken with Pope Francis beforehand. (Back in the Oval Office, President Trump restored Cuba to the terrorism list.)
Also in January, Biden awarded Pope Francis the Medal of Freedom â€œwith distinction.â€ Wall Street Journal columnist William McGurn dissented: â€œBiden will leave behind a weakened American presence on the world stage at a time of heightened global conflict. In
Rome, meanwhile, Pope Francis has diminished the papacyâ€™s moral witness in similar ways and for similar reasons.â€
McGurn noted that â€œa new book by the pope calls for an international investigation into whether Israeli actions in Gaza meet the definition of genocide. â€¦ The Vaticanâ€™s job isnâ€™t to bless wars. But under Pope Francis it appears to have abandoned just-war principlesâ€ long taught by the church and by which free Western societies defend themselves.
Alan Dershowitz, Harvard University Law School professor emeritus, called Francisâ€™ Israeli genocide innuendo a renewed antisemitic blood libel . Author Melanie Phillips said the popeâ€™s attack on an Israel fighting for its life was influenced by â€œ Palestinian Christian liberation theology â€ designating Palestinian Arabs as Jesus oppressed by the Jews.
On the fourth anniversary of the Jan. 6, 2021 U.S. Capitol riot the pope appeared to mix politics with pastoral appointments in naming San Diegoâ€™s Cardinal Robert McElroy as new archbishop of Washington, D.C. During Trumpâ€™s first term as president, McElroy criticized administration policy of separating children from illegal immigrant parents. At the news conference announcing his selection as archbishop, McElroy said Trumpâ€™s â€œwider, indiscriminate massive deportationâ€ of illegals would contradict Catholic teachings .
Pope Francis hopes to unite Chinaâ€™s â€œundergroundâ€ Catholic house churches, which are loyal to Rome, with the Beijing-dominated official branch. He wants to win full diplomatic recognition for the Vatican from Communist China, which is busy and at times brutally â€œSinicizingâ€ all religion.
In 2023 the pontiff acquiesced to Chinaâ€™s appointment of a new bishop in Shanghai . The move ignored church prerogatives and seemingly violated a 2018 Vatican-China agreement. Washington Times columnist R. Emmett Tyrrell, Jr. castigated Francis for speaking â€œgibberishâ€ about â€œrespectfulâ€ relations with China.
Similarly, the pope has had little or nothing to say about Chinaâ€™s best-known dissident, the imprisoned Catholic Jimmy Lai, and delayed for years acknowledging President Xi Jinpingâ€™s slow genocide of the Uyghurs .
Three months after Russia invaded Ukraine the pope said the â€œ barking of NATO at the door of Russiaâ€ may have led to the invasion. He deplored the warâ€™s brutality but said he did not know if other countries should supply more weapons to Kiev. Meanwhile, the head of the embattled countryâ€™s Greek Catholic Church accused Russia of killing scores of Ukrainian religious leaders and damaging or destroying hundreds of churches.
When Peruvian Rev. Gustavo Gutierrez, known as the father of â€œliberation theology,â€ died last year, obituary writers noted that Pope Benedict XVI termed liberation theology a â€œfundamental threat to the faith of the church.â€ Romanian communist defector Ion Mihai Pacepa called it â€œ Christianized Marxism .â€
But Pope Francis, under whose tenure Gutierrezâ€™s reputation improved, once described liberation theology with its â€œpreferential option for the poorâ€ as â€œ a positive thing â€ in Latin America. Complaining of a â€œ very strong reactionary attitude â€ among some U.S. Catholics, the pope in 2023 removed Bishop Joseph Strickland of Tyler, Texas. Strickland had warned that a pending Vatican synod could cast doubt on â€œbasic truths,â€ including sinfulness of sex outside of marriage and â€œundeniable biological and God-givenâ€ gender identity.
In 2018 U.S. bishops considered calling for a Vatican investigation into how Washington, D.C.â€™s Theodore McCarrick, who resigned as cardinal, climbed the church hierarchy despite years of rumors about his alleged sexual predation among seminarians. Francis reportedly was warned about McCarrick soon after becoming pope, but came to rely upon him nevertheless. Last year, Catholic World Report castigated the pope for talking a good game about abusive homosexual priests but failing to achieve real reform.
The Catholic Church is one of the worldâ€™s largest institutions. The beliefs and actions of its leader matter to non-Catholics as well. In that context, Francis has failed us.
Eric Rozenman is author, most recently, of From Elvis to Trump, Eyewitness to the Unraveling: Co-Starring Richard Nixon, Andy Warhol, Bill Clinton, The Supremes and Barack Obama!

author: GRETCHEN TESKE gteske@qctimes.com
title: Rock Island police arrest shooting suspect Thursday
text: A suspect was arrested by Rock Island police Thursday afternoon, hours after allegedly shooting his co-worker. Dante T. Beard, 30, was arrested after the Rock Island Police Department's Emergency Response Team and Rock Island County Sheriffâ€™s Office Emergency Response Team served a search warrant on Beard who was wanted for aggravated battery with a firearm. Beard was arrested at the American Motor Inn Thursday afternoon, less than three miles from where he allegedly shot a co-worker that morning. Just after 8 a.m., police responded to Pak Source at 690 Mill Street in Rock Island where they found a 34-year-old man with a gunshot wound to his torso. The victim was transported to UnityPoint Health-Trinity Hospital for treatment where his wounds appeared to be serious, but non-life threatening, police announced Thursday morning. People are also readingâ€¦ There was no update on the victim's condition Thursday afternoon. Police at the scene surmised the victim had a confrontation with his co-worker, Beard, who reportedly pulled out a handgun, shot the victim and left the scene. Beard was arrested just before 1:45 p.m. Thursday and transported to the Rock Island Police Department awaiting transfer to the Rock Island County Jail pending a first court appearance. The incident remains under investigation by the Rock Island Police Departmentâ€™s Criminal Investigation Division. No further information was available as of Thursday afternoon. Anyone with addition information is asked to contact the Rock Island Police Department at (309) 732-2677 or Crime Stoppers at (309) 762-9500 or using the P3 Tips app. Violent crime is up â€¦ and also down, according to new federal data Violent crime is up â€¦ and also down, according to new federal data Federal reports show similar long-term trends in violent crime, but diverge significantly on year-over-year changes Despite the long-term trends, the two reports differ more than ever before on the year-over-year change in violent crime. Property crime went up in 2022 One undeniable trend: Violent crimes against young people doubled
